definition: lit. to be muddled in the brain (idiom); fig. excited and unable to act rationally/to go to one's head
lit. to be muddled in the brain (idiom); fig. excited and unable to act rationally/to go to one's head
powerful/vigorous/pungent/towards/in view of
thoroughfare/to go straight ahead/to rush/to clash
(of water) to dash against/to mix with water/to infuse/to rinse/to flush/to develop (a film)/to rise in the air/to clash/to collide with
muddle-headed/twilight/to faint/to lose consciousness

suffix for nouns
head/hair style/the top/end/beginning or end/a stub/remnant/chief/boss/side/aspect/first/leading/classifier for pigs or livestock/CL:個|个[ge4]
brain/mind/head/essence

sentences.english: Miguel is a young Colombian politician blinded by his own privilege.
sentences.chinese: 米格尔是个被特权冲昏头脑的哥伦比亚政治家。

sentences.english: He is carried away by his own success.
sentences.chinese: 他被自己的成就冲昏头脑。

sentences.english: Sir, you've gone mad with power!
sentences.chinese: 先生，您被权力冲昏头脑了。

sentences.english: She has not allowed success to turn her head.
sentences.chinese: 她没有让成功冲昏头脑。

sentences.english: Because you might get carried away.
sentences.chinese: 因为你可能会被它冲昏头脑。

sentences.english: I'm not getting carried away with it, only the media will.
sentences.chinese: 我不会被联赛杯冠军而冲昏头脑，只有媒体会。

sentences.english: He warned them against suffering giddiness from success.
sentences.chinese: 他警告他们，不要让胜利冲昏头脑。

definition: to deceive/to hoodwink
so pleased as to lose one's sense of measure/beside oneself with joy
to get carried away/to forget oneself
reason/intellect/rationality/rational
to act impetuously (idiom); on an impulse
to puzzle/to confuse/to baffle
to lead by the nose
to let emotions affect one's decisions
immeasurably self-satisfied
graceful words, flowery speech (idiom); elegant but insincere words/cheating wheedling/dishonest rhetoric
to covet/to seek (riches, fame)
to have an urge/to be impetuous/impulse/urge
(idiom) to lose one's head/to panic/to go to pieces
to advance prematurely
to belittle/to scorn/to take sth lightly
sugar-coated bullets, term used by Mao (originally in 1949) to refer to corrupting bourgeois influences
